column4: ok, to test if a joystick device is working, you'd do a 'od -xw8 /dev/input/js0', right? the output values are supposed to change while you're pessing buttons, right?

i'm trying to get a PSX pad (via PSX-USB converter) working under ubuntu 6.06 and its not going so well. it started working one day and i don't know why, and it stopped working when i unplugged it and plugged it back in.
possibly hung the usb port for that device
any way to check?
on replugging it back in - it may have assumed a difference device address
check your sys log for starters
is there anything i should keep my eyes out for?
errr usb and devices and playstation for example
ok - so you can see its being recognised
but whenever i try to configure in padjoy, it looks like it gets the device file opened, but doesn't receive input
I've given you pointers on where and what to look for. What device ID is it currently using ?
is it this? [HID 0925:8866]
no I mean what unix device file is it using

ok - so 1.) check that file exists, and the status of it, 2.) Check the sylog to see if it still believes its using that device 3.) check for other jsX devices to see if any new ones have been created

i did #1 using 'cat /dev/input/js0' and 'od -xw8 /dev/input/js0' and getting back random characters (values in the case of od), the syslog doesn't seem to report anything other then finding the device, the last thing listed in dmesg is about a hdd error and in the system log its from gconf, and  and i don't see any other jsX devices in the /dev/input folder.
looks like the pad configuration software is having an issue then
try rebooting (lame I know)
i just came from a reboot
no idea, never used the PS2 pads
you could try it
its actually a PS1
ok- never tried a PS1 pad
